fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.bodyText: • We quoted Chris McCabe of the University of Leeds commenting on the high cost to the UK health system of using some new drugs: "Breast cancer treatments are £60,000 per patient per year. Colorectal cancer drugs are about £20,000." We should have made clear that he was saying treatments could be up to these maximum sums (Emergency fund to pay for 'too expensive' cancer drugs, 28 July, page 8). • In a piece about damages awarded in a court case where a member of an Afghan family sued the author of The Bookseller of Kabul, Åsne Seierstad, we omitted to mention where the proceedings took place – Oslo district court (Brought to book: Kabul author guilty of 'betraying' a nation, 28 July, page 11). • It was runner Chris Thompson, not his team-mate Mo Farah, who said after winning a silver medal in the 10,000 metres in Barcelona on Tuesday: "I felt like I was in the coliseum with all the noise and the cheering" (Golden moment, 28 July, page 1, Sport). • Baited breath, which featured in this column's homophone corner on 24 July, made further appearances in yesterday's paper. In a football piece, we twice had Aston Villa's Martin O'Neill waiting "with baited breath" (City refusing to meet asking price for Milner deal, claims O'Neill, 28 July, page 4, Sport). A comment piece mentioned "waiting with baited breath" for a pronouncement by the chief UN weapons inspector in Iraq (Too late, Blix, too late, 28 July, page 30). • This column was amended on 29 July. The original referred to Manchester City's Martin O'Neill. This has been corrected, and a print correction will also follow.
